sub_topic: Calculating the enthalpy and entropy of inorganic reactions
message_1: What is the change in entropy (ΔS) when 2 moles of ammonia (NH3) react with 3 moles of oxygen gas (O2) to produce 2 moles of nitrogen gas (N2) and 6 moles of water vapor (H2O) at a constant pressure and temperature of 25°C and 1 atm? Given that the standard molar entropies of NH3, O2, N2, and H2O are 192.45 J/K·mol, 205.03 J/K·mol, 191.61 J/K·mol, and 188.72 J/K·mol, respectively.
message_2:
To calculate the change in entropy (ΔS) for the reaction, we can use the formula:

ΔS = ΣnS(products) - ΣnS(reactants)

where n is the number of moles of each substance and S is the standard molar entropy of each substance.

For the given reaction:

2 NH3 (g) + 3 O2 (g) → 2 N2 (g) + 6 H2O (g)

The change in entropy (ΔS) can be calculated as follows:

ΔS = [2 moles N2 × 191.61 J/K·mol + 6 moles H2O × 188.72 J/K·mol] - [2 moles NH3 × 192.45 J/K·mol + 3 moles O2 × 205.03 J/K·mol]

ΔS = [2 × 191.61 + 6 × 188.72] - [2 × 192.45 + 3 × 205.03]

ΔS = [383.22 + 1132.32] - [384.9 + 615.09]

ΔS = 1515.54 - 999.99

ΔS = 515.55 J/K

So the change in entropy (ΔS) for the reaction is 515.55 J/K.
